isis.stitle: VT 275 Engine Service Manual - Dual Turbocharger and Exhaust Tubing - Cleaning and Inspection - Visual and Mechanical Inspection

note.para: Replace turbocharger if any bent blades are found. Do not attempt to straighten bent wheel blades.
Compressor impeller and turbine wheel deposits can be caused by the following:

item.para: High Air Inlet Restriction allows oil to transfer from the turbocharger center housing, resulting in oil deposits.
Excessive Oil Consumption can result in turbine wheel carbon deposits.
Engine Over Fueling can result in excessive operating temperatures which can cause aluminum components to melt. Such deposits may be found on either turbine wheel if such a failure occurs.

step1.para: Place turbocharger on a bench with shaft in a horizontal position.

figure.caption: Checking turbocharger for free wheel rotation

step1.para: Shaft must spin freely when turned by hand. Inspect turbine and compressor housing for evidence of wheel rubbing, blade erosion, bending, or breakage. Replace turbocharger assembly if any of these conditions are found.
Perform same steps on adjacent turbocharger.
Inspect supply line for kinking, clogging, restrictions and other signs of deterioration. Discard both sets of O-rings.
Inspect oil drain tube for clogging, restrictions and other signs of deterioration.
With turbocharger in a stable position, place tip of Dial Indicator with Magnetic Base onto end of shaft (turbine side). See Special Service Tools.

step2.para: Push shaft in either direction and hold in position.
Zero dial indicator face and needle.
Pull shaft in opposite direction and record measured distance on dial face.
If measurement exceeds Specifications, turbocharger assembly must be replaced.

step1.para: Perform the previous steps on adjacent turbocharger.

figure.caption: Left - boost control test setup, Right - actuator rod

step1.para: Proceed with the following steps to inspect the boost control actuator:

step2.para: Remove tubing from boost control diaphragm.
Connect shop air and pressure regulator to the boost control diaphragm.
Slowly regulate shop air to approximately 103 kPa (15 psi) and observe actuator arm. It should begin to move at this pressure.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, do not exceed 207 kPa (30 psi) as damage to the diaphragm may result.

step2.para: If the actuator rod does not begin to move at 103 kPa (15 psi) or if diaphragm is leaking, replace dual turbocharger assembly.
